items.description: North Sea coast at Bridlington
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast tomorrow, Sunday 7th November between 04:30 and 08:00am. The particular areas at risk are exposed frontages and paths around Bridlington and low paths around Bridlington Harbour. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides on Sunday and Monday, after which we expect tidal conditions to improve. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 9PM on Saturday 6th November 2021.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
Christchurch Harbour
items.message:
As a result of Forecast high spring tides will raise water levels in the harbour. This is expected to result in standing water affecting footpaths and low lying land on the seaward side of flood defences.  Forecast high water is 10:45 on 07/11/21 with a level of 1.24 mAOD and a Force 3 West wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and properties is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon   
The maximum forecast tidal height is 1.24m AOD.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this evening, 07/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the coastline between Whitby to Filey including Scarborough this afternoon, Saturday 6th November between 15:30 and 17:30, and again tomorrow morning, Sunday 7th November between 04:00 and 08:00. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Scarborough, particularly low lying paths around Scarborough South Bay. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides on Sunday and Monday, after which we expect tidal conditions to improve. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 9PM on Saturday 6th November 2021.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 15:30 on 06/11/21 may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 48 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 07/11/21, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast and the eastern part of the Humber Estuary tomorrow, Sunday 7th November between 05:30 and 09:30am. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Kilnsea and Spurn Point. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides on Sunday and Monday, after which we expect tidal conditions to improve. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 9PM on Saturday 6th November 2021.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of high spring tides and strong winds at Seahouses, Newbiggin Bay, Beadnell Harbour Road North and Alnmouth. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 02:30 AM and 06:30 AM tomorrow morning, 07/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 to 4 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Our incident duty staff are monitoring the situation and will issue Flood Warnings if required.
Spring tides peak over the weekend and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides on Sunday, 07/11/2021. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Sunday 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message: High water levels are forecast this evening as a result of spring tides and increased wind speeds. First forecast high water is 19:45 on 6/11/21 with a level of 6.76 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. Second forecast high water is 08:15 on 7/11/21 with a level of 6.36 mAOD and a Force 6 NorthWesterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland may be possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides at 20:30 on 7/11/21. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 13:00 on Sunday, 7/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual.  Tides will be at their highest at 07:15 tomorrow morning, 07/11/21. Flooding to properties/roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.  

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest overnight at 12:01 AM on 07/11/2021.
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods at 12:01 AM on 07/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 06:30 AM on 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at midnight on 06/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.
The forecast is for strong winds throughout the evening and tomorrow.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts and warnings.
Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated within 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
High tidal levels are expected to overtop sea defences.  The first forecast high water is at 20:15 on 06/11/21 with a level of 7.76 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. The second forecast high water is at 08:30 on 07/11/21 with a level of 7.42 mAOD and a Force 5 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  
This message will be updated by 11:00 on Sunday, 07/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message: The high tide is expected to be higher than usual at the Mersey Estuary at Warrington as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads this afternoon, on Saturday 6th November, in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry, peak level of 6.45m at 12:45pm, Eastford Road, peak level of 6.61m at 1:00pm, and Arpley Bridge, peak level of 6.66m at 1:15pm. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. High tides are also expected for this evening and tomorrow afternoon, Sunday 7th November. A flood warning for tonightâ€™s tide at Arpley Bridge is possible. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
A series of high spring tides and strong winds are expected over the weekend. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.8m to 8.1m at 20:15 on 06/11/21, Newport 7.3m to 7.6m at 20:00 on 06/11/21. Tides will be at their highest between 19:30 and 20:45. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.     

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with our partners.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 22:00 on 06/11/21, or if the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tides from Friday evening 5th November until Saturday evening 6th November associated with large spring tides. 
The time of high water at Ilfracombe on Friday evening is at 6:10pm, and the water level at high tide is forecast to be 5.05m AOD on Friday building to 5.16m AOD on Saturday with winds forecast to be Westerly Force 4 strengthening to Force 6 on Saturday evening, and offshore wave heights of up to 2.5m. Wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations is possible at Ilfracombe and Lynmouth.  Expect tides to be around 150mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

items.description: Lune estuary south west of Lancaster
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest overnight at 12:01 AM on 07/11/2021.
Areas most at risk include Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson and Thurnham Moss.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Aldcliffe Marsh, Heaton Marsh, Marsh, Greyhound Bridge, Skerton Bridge, Newton, Overton, Middleton, Glasson and Thurnham Moss at 12:01 AM on 07/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.
We are closing locks and flood gates in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 06:30 AM on 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
High spring tides and strong winds are expected this evening in the Severn Estuary. 
Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences where defences are present including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. Fluvial tidal interaction may cause minor flooding during the high tide at Gloucester and Sandhurst. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks: Sharpness 10m to 10.3m at 20:45 on 06/11/21, Sandhurst 2.9m to 3.2m at 22:30 on 6/11/21, Gloucester 3m to 3.3m.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 22:00 on 06/11/21, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary at Brockweir
items.message:
High spring tides and strong winds will cause high tidal peaks on The River Wye over the next two days. Tides will be at their highest between 19:30 and 21:00 tonight, the 06/11/21. Flooding to properties, roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. High tides may impact garages & footpaths in Brockweir. Predicted peaks: Avonmouth Portbury 7.8m to 8.1m at 20:15, Newport 7.3m to 7.6m at 20:00.   

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 22:00 on 06/11/21, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding of areas near the Wash Frontage in Lincolnshire
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in large waves moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday morning. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the Wash Frontage. The time and date of the forecast high water is 07:15 on 7th November 2021, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash causing localised pooling of water behind the sea defences.  Low lying coastal land and roads will be affected first.  Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides on Sunday and Monday, after which we expect tidal conditions to improve. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 9PM on Saturday 6th November 2021.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High Spring tides and a minor surge from a low pressure system are expected to cause higher than usual levels tomorrow morning, 07/11/2021. Tides will be at their highest between 03:45 AM and 05:00 AM, 07/11/2021. Flooding to low lying land, footpaths and roads is possible during these times and conditions may apply 2 to 4 hours either side of the high tide. The area along the Estuary most at risk is Newcastle Quayside. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Spring tides peak over the weekend and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides on Sunday, 07/11/2021. Our incident duty staff are monitoring the situation closely and will issue Flood Warnings if required. This message will be updated at 10:00 AM, 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 5:15am and 9:15am Sunday 7th November. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.81mAODN at 7:15am, on Sunday 7th of November, which is 0.51m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. It is likely the alert may be re-issued for Sunday evening's tide. This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7th November.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 5:15am and 9:15am on Sunday 7 November. Flood water may be present on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.81mAODN at 7:15am, on Sunday 7 of November, which is 0.51m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. It is likely the alert may be re-issued for Sunday evening's tide. This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7 November.

items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. The total forecast tide is 5.27 metres Chart Datum (2.54 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, levels will be high at South Street and Queen Street Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park at Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the bottom third of Langstone High Street, although flood depths in the road will be relatively shallow. After this tideâ€š no further impacts are expected. In Emsworth, we will lower levels in the Mill Pond. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will remove this message by 16:00 on 07/11/2021.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
High water levels are forecast this evening as a result of very high spring tides and increased wind speeds. Sea spray may overtop coastal defences. Forecast high water is 20:15 on 6/11/21 with a level of 7.79 mAOD and a Force 4 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland may be possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. The area most at risk is the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade.   
Tidal levels are not expected to meet the Flood Alert threshold for the 7/11/21 high tide at 08:30. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 7/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Minehead, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea and Uphill to Kingston Seymour
items.message: High water levels are forecast this evening as a result of very high spring tides and increased wind speeds. Sea spray may overtop coastal defences. Forecast high water is 19:45 on 6/11/21 with a level of 6.76 mAOD and a Force 6 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level; for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland may be possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are coastal and tidal areas at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour. Water levels are not expected to meet the Flood Alert threshold for the 7/11/21 high tide at 08:00. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 7/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Bacton to Ostend, including Walcott
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 5:30am and 9:30am on Sunday 7 November. The Coast road at Walcott may see some wave overtopping and spray. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.22 mAODN at 7:30am, on Sunday 7 November, which is 0.59m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly, which will be blowing strongly offshore. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. It is likely the alert may be re-issued for Sunday evening's tide. This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7 November.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Eccles on Sea, to and including, Winterton-on-Sea
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 5:30am and 9:30am on Sunday 7th November. High tides will mean flood gates will be closed restricting normal access to beaches around Eccles on Sea, and Sea Palling. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.22mAODN at 7:30am, on Sunday 7th of November, which is 0.59m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. It is likely the alert may be re-issued for Sunday evening's tide. This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7th November.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 8:15am and 12:15pm on Sunday 7 November. We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.08 mAODN at 10:15am, on Sunday 7 November, which is 0.80m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly, which will be blowing strongly offshore. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on roads and footpaths at the coast and in the estuaries, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. It is possible we may need to re-issue the alert for Sunday evening's tide. This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7 November.

items.description: Tidal flooding near the South Humber Bank from Whitton to South Ferriby
items.message: Stormy conditions are forecast, resulting in large waves moving down the East Coast of England on Sunday morning. This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the South Humber Bank, between Whitton and South Ferriby. The time and date of the forecast high water is 06:30 on 7th November 2021, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash, causing localised pooling of water behind the sea defences. Low lying coastal land and roads will be affected first. Our forecasts currently indicate that the closure of the A1077 flood gate isn't required and flooding to properties is not expected. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Caister to Gorleston, including Great Yarmouth
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 8:00am and midday on Sunday 7th November. We expect high tide levels at Gorleston-on-Sea and water on towpaths and quaysides throughout Great Yarmouth. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Great Yarmouth of 2.07mAODN at 10:00am, on Sunday 7th of November, which is 0.83m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly, which will be blowing strongly offshore. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7th November.

This will lead to unusually high tidal levels along the South Humber Bank between Barton Upon Humber to Humberston. The time and date of the forecast high water is 06:45 on 7th November 2021, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. The high tides combined with strong winds may result in wind-blown spray and wave splash causing localised pooling of water behind the sea defences.  Low lying coastal land and roads will be affected first.  Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring tide levels, and have staff in the field checking our defences and closing tidal gates where required. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths near beaches or promenades and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, as sea spray and waves could be dangerous. items.description: Ribble estuary west of Preston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest overnight at 12:01 AM on 07/11/2021.
Areas most at risk include Freckleton Marsh, Riversway Docklands, Lower Penwortham, Hutton Marsh, Longton Marsh, Becconsall Marsh, Much Hoole Marsh, Bretherton Eyes, Croston Finney, Hesketh Out Marsh and Hundred End.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Freckleton Marsh, Riversway Docklands, Lower Penwortham, Hutton Marsh, Longton Marsh, Becconsall Marsh, Much Hoole Marsh, Bretherton Eyes, Croston Finney, Hesketh Out Marsh and Hundred End at 12:01 AM on 07/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 06:30 AM on 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Aire catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message:
This alert is being issued due to the possibility of minor impacts from tidal and coastal flooding on Sunday 7th November. Some of the highest tides of the year are expected over this weekend, and the forecast shows that , due to the local weather conditions, Sunday morningâ€™s tide will be particularly high . The highest levels along the tidal River Aire are expected around 8am to 9:30 a.m Sunday morning. 
We do not currently anticipate issuing flood warnings in this area, however we will be monitoring the situation in case there are any changes to the forecast. Our operational staff will be out inspecting our flood defences before and after the peak tides, and we are liaising closely with our partners. 
Please keep away from flood water and to report an issue relating to river, tidal or coastal flooding, call our Incident Hotline 0800 80 70 60. Be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation via our Check for Flooding Service on Gov.UK or via Floodline 0345 988 1188. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Morecambe Bay area
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest overnight at 12:01 AM on 07/11/2021.
Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast overnight.
Areas most at risk include Warton, Carnforth, Crag Bank, Bolton-le-Sands, Hest Bank, Bare, Torrisholme, Great Hestham and Heysham Harbour.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Warton, Carnforth, Crag Bank, Bolton-le-Sands, Hest Bank, Bare, Torrisholme, Great Hestham and Heysham Harbour at 12:01 AM on 07/11/2021. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 06:30 AM on 07/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 8:15am and 12:15pm on Sunday 7th November. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.08mAODN at 10:15am, on Sunday 7th November, which is 0.80m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Westerly, which will be blowing strongly offshore. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on roads and footpaths at the coast and around the Blyth Estuary, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. It is possible we may need to re-issue the alert for Sunday evening's tide.

The highest levels are expected on Sunday morning around 7:45-8:45am. 
We will be monitoring the situation closely in case we need to issue any flood warnings  ahead of Sunday morningâ€™s high tide. Our operational staff will be out inspecting our flood defences before and after the peak tides, and we are liaising closely with our partners.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 8am tomorrow morning, Sunday 7 November, and for at least the next 24hrs. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth tomorrow will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea, resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  It is likely that we may need to re-issue the flood alert for Sunday evening's tide. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  This message will be updated by 11am tomorrow, Sunday 7 November.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 8am tomorrow morning, Sunday 7th November, and for at least the next 24 hours. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth tomorrow will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  It is likely that we may need to re-issue the flood alert for Sunday evening's tide. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  This message will be updated by 4pm tomorrow, Sunday 7th November.

items.description: Selsey Bill to Elmer
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.27 m. The total forecast tide is 6.41 metres Chart Datum (3.36 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 1 hour either side of high water, Mill Lane, Sidlesham will flood, making access temporarily more difficult. After this tideâ€š no further impacts are expected. Monday's tides are forecast to be at least 30cm lower and accompanied with lighter winds and smaller waves. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. Avoid driving on Mill Lane, Sidlesham at high tide, flood water can contain hidden dangers. We will update this message by 15:00 on 07/11/2021.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.27 m. The total forecast tide is 6.41 metres Chart Datum (3.36 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high water, the tide will cause flooding to boatyards and the industrial areas along Littlehampton Rope Walk. Water will be high up slipways and could be forced up through drains causing minor flooding to roads. After this tideâ€š no further impacts are expected. Monday's tides are forecast to be at least 30cm lower and accompanied with lighter winds and smaller waves. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 2 hours before high tide, in Littlehampton Rope Walk. We will update this message by 15:00 on 07/11/2021.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.27 m. The total forecast tide is 6.41 metres Chart Datum (3.36 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, a small amount of water may pond on nearby land, fields and at Climping Street Car Park. If the waves are a little larger than currently forecast, a small amount of water may then flow westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards residential property in Climping Street. After this tideâ€š no further impacts are expected. Monday's tides are forecast to be at least 30cm lower and accompanied with lighter winds and smaller waves. We continue to monitor the forecast. We have recycled shingle at Climping in advance of this weekend. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 15:00 on 07/11/2021.

items.description: Thorney Island to Bracklesham
items.message: Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:45 on 07/11/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong North Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.19 m. The total forecast tide is 5.25 metres Chart Datum (2.51 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide might flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or flood front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the Harbour could also be affected. After this tideâ€š no further impacts are expected. Monday's tides are forecast to be at least 30cm lower and accompanied with lighter winds and smaller waves. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 15:00 on 07/11/2021.

items.description: Tidal Trent for riverside areas from Gainsborough to the Humber confluence

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Lincolnshire, North Lincolnshire, Nottinghamshire

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Keadby river gauge as a result of high spring tides and strong winds causing a tidal surge.  Flooding is possible on high tides at approximately 08:15, tomorrow morning, 07/11/21 at Keadby. Areas most at risk are Keadby, Amcotts, Owston, Burringham, Gunness, Althorpe, East Butterwick, Flixborough, Gunness Lane and, Neap House road.

We expect river levels to remain high until after the high tide at 09:00 on 07/11/21 at Keadby.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/11/21, or as the situation changes.
